entities.name: FTX Trading Ltd.

attributes.type: cryptocurrency exchange and crypto hedge fund

entities.context: FTX Trading Ltd., trading as FTX (Futures Exchange), is a bankrupt company that formerly operated a cryptocurrency exchange and crypto hedge fund.

entities.name: Sam Bankman-Fried
entities.context: The exchange was founded in 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried and Gary Wang and collapsed in 2022 after massive fraud perpetrated by Bankman-Fried

entities.name: Gary Wang
entities.context: Sam Bankman-Fried and Zixiao "Gary" Wang founded FTX in May 2019.

entities.name: Caroline Ellison
entities.context: Caroline Ellison, who had served as Alameda's CEO, pleaded guilty to multiple charges

entities.name: John J. Ray III

attributes.experience: Enron, Residential Capital, Nortel, Overseas Shipholding bankruptcies

entities.context: John J. Ray III, the CEO brought in as a liquidator

entities.name: Changpeng Zhao

attributes.investment: purchased 20% stake in FTX for approximately $100 million

entities.context: Changpeng Zhao of Binance purchased a 20% stake in FTX for approximately $100 million

entities.name: Brett Harrison
entities.context: On September 27, 2022, FTX.US President Brett Harrison announced he would be stepping down from an active role

entities.name: Alameda Research
entities.context: its subsidiary Alameda Research had on September 30 lent $1 billion to Bankman-Fried

entities.name: Binance

attributes.actions: signed letter of intent to acquire FTX, withdrew offer next day

entities.context: rival exchange Binance's CEO Changpeng Zhao announced that Binance would sell its holdings

entities.context: FTX is closely associated with FTX.US, a separate exchange available to US residents.

entities.context: BlockFi, a cryptocurrency lender, was reportedly taking steps to file for bankruptcy

attributes.cause: massive fraud perpetrated by Bankman-Fried and Caroline Ellison

entities.context: On December 12, 2022, founder Sam Bankman-Fried was arrested by the Bahamian authorities for financial offences, at the request of the US government.

attributes.action: signed letter of intent to acquire FTX, withdrew offer next day

The exchange was founded in 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried and Gary Wang
collapsed in 2022 after massive fraud perpetrated by Bankman-Fried and his partner Caroline Ellison

FTX is incorporated in Antigua and Barbuda and headquartered in the Bahamas

Anonymous sources cited by Bloomberg said that the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York had begun an investigation into FTX's collapse as of November 14, 2022.
According to anonymous sources cited by The Information, some venture capital firms are considering suing Bankman-Fried.

Risk management firm Titan Grey published a primer on the commencement and early motions practice of the FTX chapter 11 case, analyzing issues such as creditor privacy, relief from the automatic stay, proposed differential treatment of customers from other creditors, and others.

On December 13, 2022, FTX founder and CEO Sam Bankman-Fried was charged by the US attorney's office for the southern district of New York with fraud, conspiracy to commit money laundering, and conspiracy to defraud the US and violate campaign finance laws.
After being extradited from the Bahamas, Bankman-Fried was released on a $250 million bond and ordered to remain under house arrest at his parents' home in Palo Alto, California.
He was arraigned in federal court in Manhattan on January 3, 2023, and entered a plea of not guilty to all counts.
Meanwhile, Gary Wang, co-founder of FTX, and Caroline Ellison, who had served as Alameda's CEO, pleaded guilty to multiple charges and began cooperating with federal prosecutors.
Meanwhile, Gary Wang, co-founder of FTX, and Caroline Ellison, who had served as Alameda's CEO, pleaded guilty to multiple charges and began cooperating with federal prosecutors.
Former FTX executive Ryan Salame pleaded guilty to both a campaign finance law violation and a charge of operating an unlicensed money transmitting business.
FTX's former engineering director, Nishad Singh pleaded guilty to six different charges, including three counts of conspiracy to commit fraud.
Singh is a childhood friend of Bankman-Fried's brother and worked at Alameda Research before being brought into FTX.

Deals included the naming rights to the Miami Heat's basketball stadium, renaming it FTX Arena, a partnership with Major League Baseball to place the FTX logo on the uniforms of umpires, and a deal with Mercedes-AMG Petronas F1 Team to add the FTX logo to their cars and merchandise.
